title: Grain Storage | Storage Hygiene and Structural Treatments

tasks.task: Perform hygiene and structural treatments for grain storage.
subtasks: Clean up grain storage areas and surroundings.
Remove leftover grain and debris from grain bins, headers, and trucks.
Apply diatomaceous earth (DE) as a structural treatment in grain bins and equipment.
Use a blow back gun or leaf blower to distribute DE evenly inside grain bins.
Apply DE as a slurry on shed walls and internal surfaces for additional protection.
Wear protective gear (dust mask, gloves, goggles) when handling DE.
Dispose of waste grain properly instead of leaving it in piles or buckets.
Clean grain headers and machinery, especially at the end of each season.
Ensure proper design and maintenance of grain storage structures (e.g., concrete pads, easy-to-clean surfaces).
Apply pesticides or other structural treatments around grain storage areas if necessary.
Maintain low humidity levels in grain storage areas to prevent pest activity.
Follow recommended timing for hygiene and DE treatments (late summer/early spring).
Dispose of DE residues in areas where high-value crops like pulses and oil seeds will not be stored.
Monitor grain storage regularly for signs of pest activity.

tasks.task: Conduct Q&A sessions during webinars to address viewer concerns.
subtasks: Encourage participants to submit questions via the Q&A window during the webinar.
Respond to questions about the use of DE around silos and provide alternative treatments.
Inform participants about additional resources (storedgrain.com.au, hotline number) for further assistance.

tasks.task: Perform hygiene and structural treatments for grain storage.
Conduct Q&A sessions during webinars to address viewer concerns.
